G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as the property and the events at issue are located in Springfield, Hampden County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as the property and the events at issue are located in Springfield, Hampden County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord shall not directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the rented premises.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.proposition: Massachusetts recognizes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in every residential tenancy.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly refers to an "implied covenant" or "implied warranty" of quiet enjoyment and analyzes whether the landlords breached that covenant with respect to residential tenants. The court treats this covenant as a given feature of the landlord‑tenant relationship and applies it to residential leases, thus recognizing an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in every residential tenancy. Although the opinion does not use the phrase "every residential tenancy," it clearly assumes and applies an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment to these residential tenancies as a matter of general landlord‑tenant law.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.relevant_excerpt: The judge found that the tenants were “very substantially deprived” of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises “for a substantial time” (emphasis original). He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). … Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment…

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Landlord liability arises from both affirmative acts and omissions.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court explicitly grounds landlord liability in a duty to maintain habitable, sanitary premises, and it upholds liability based on the landlord’s failure to act—its omission to repair a porous wall and prevent recurrent flooding. The opinion repeatedly characterizes the wrongful conduct as an “omission to act” and emphasizes that liability can arise where the landlord “fails to maintain” habitable conditions, confirming that omissions as well as affirmative acts can give rise to landlord liability.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “We have held that every landlord that rents residential property warrants to its tenants that the premises will be delivered and maintained in a habitable condition… At a minimum, this warranty imposes on the landlord a duty to keep the dwelling in conformity with the State Sanitary Code… Further, a landlord that fails to maintain a habitable dwelling for its tenant is liable for resulting personal injuries… In sum, it could be found that Gem violated its duty to Solomon recklessly, by outrageous omission to act, and thereby caused Solomon severe emotional harm.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The covenant protects tenants against “substantial interference with the tenants’ beneficial enjoyment of the premises.”
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court expressly defines the scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in this case, stating that it protects tenants from serious interference with their tenancy that impairs the character and value of the leasehold. Later the court characterizes the interference here as “serious” and “substantially” impairing the tenancy if the tenants cannot use common areas. This aligns with and supports the stated proposition that the covenant protects tenants against substantial interference with their beneficial enjoyment of the premises.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.” (417 Mass. at 284-85)

Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.proposition: Failure to repair essential services such as electricity, heat, or water constitutes a breach.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.support_reasoning: The court explicitly notes that, as part of the landlord’s wrongful interference, there were interruptions of electric and water service to the leased premises, and that these interruptions contributed to liability for damages. While the opinion is framed in terms of wrongful interference and nuisance rather than “breach of covenant to repair,” it clearly treats the failure to maintain essential services (electricity and water) during the remodeling as part of the actionable wrong against the tenant. Thus it supports the proposition that deprivation of such essential services constitutes a breach of the landlord’s obligations to the tenant.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.relevant_excerpt: “Even though the work was carried on in a reasonable and proper manner and entirely outside the rooms leased, injury was done to the property and appliances used in those rooms; **there were interruptions of the electric and water service therein**, the plaintiff’s right of access was made more difficult, his property was injured, and he suffered a loss of income in business. The finding that the work was done outside and was properly done is not a controlling circumstance.”

Berman & Sons v. Perlman, 343 Mass. 547,.proposition: Failure to repair essential services such as electricity, heat, or water constitutes a breach.
Berman & Sons v. Perlman, 343 Mass. 547,.case_name: Quintin Vespa Co. Inc. v. Construction Service Co.
Berman & Sons v. Perlman, 343 Mass. 547,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns allocation of contractual duties between a contractor and subcontractor regarding excavation, sheeting, shoring, and site preparation. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, habitability, or essential residential services such as electricity, heat, or water. The holding is about which party breached by failing to prepare and maintain the job site, not about failure to repair essential services constituting a breach, so it does not support the stated proposition.
Berman & Sons v. Perlman, 343 Mass. 547,.relevant_excerpt: “Paragraph (14) imposed on Vespa the duty ‘to prepare and maintain the job site’ so that the work… could go on continuously. This provision in terms is broad enough to require Vespa to do whatever might become necessary (including any necessary sheeting and shoring) to maintain the job site in such condition that the work at no time would be impeded.… Vespa’s failure was a material prevention of performance by Construction and a breach of a duty imposed upon Vespa by the contract which excused Construction from further performance.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 853 (.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold landlords liable under this section for failing to repair serious defects.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 853 (.support_reasoning: The case does not say that Massachusetts courts "consistently hold landlords liable" for failure to repair serious defects. Instead, it clarifies that liability under G.L. c. 186, §14 requires at least negligent conduct with notice or reason to know, and it expressly rejects strict liability based solely on a statutory violation. While the opinion notes that failure to repair known defects can violate §14, it frames this as requiring proof of fault, not automatic or consistent liability.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 853 (.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord…

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907, 909 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: The duty is nondelegable; landlords cannot excuse performance by citing contractor or structural delays.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with a landlord’s statutory duties under the State Sanitary Code, the security deposit statute, and rent control, but it does not address any issue of a nondelegable duty with respect to performance being excused by contractor or structural delays. There is no discussion of landlords attempting to justify nonperformance based on third-party contractors or construction delays, nor any holding that such duties are nondelegable in that sense. The case is therefore not authority for the claimed proposition.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: The State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.190 and 410.201 (1983), provides that the owner of a dwelling “shall” supply heat and hot water “except and to the extent that the occupant is required to supply the fuel under a written letting agreement.” … The plain and unambiguous language of the regulation indicates that a writing is required when the obligation to provide heat and hot water is transferred to the tenant.

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: The existence of unsafe or unusable rooms is sufficient interference even absent total deprivation of possession.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The case holds that failure to provide heat, a required service, constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment, but it does not analyze partial versus total deprivation of possession or discuss unsafe or unusable *rooms* as a distinct interference. The opinion focuses on the lack of heat in the apartment generally and does not articulate a rule that unsafe or unusable rooms alone are sufficient interference absent total deprivation of possession. Thus it is related conceptually but does not clearly support the specific proposition stated.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Hemingway v. Boston Housing Auth., 363 M.raw_text: Hemingway v. Boston Housing Auth., 363 Mass. 184, 198–202 (1973)
Hemingway v. Boston Housing Auth., 363 M.proposition: The covenant exists independently of and in addition to any contractual lease obligations.
Hemingway v. Boston Housing Auth., 363 M.support_reasoning: The concurring/dissenting opinion describes the landlord’s obligation as an implied agreement or covenant that incorporates statutory and code standards directly into the lease itself. It expressly characterizes this duty as part of the lease contract, not as an obligation existing independently of contractual lease obligations. Thus, the case, particularly this opinion, does not support the proposition that the covenant exists independently of and in addition to the lease; instead it grounds the obligation within the contractual relationship.
Hemingway v. Boston Housing Auth., 363 M.relevant_excerpt: The net result of this court’s interpretation of these statutes was ... that if he rented the unit without correcting the violations the statutes did not per se impose an obligation on him for the benefit of the tenant to correct the violations... As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant...
